devsite_speakers.bio: Francesco is an Engineering Manager on the Android team responsible for device cloud messaging.

Richard is a Developer Advocate for Android at Google in the UK. He has enjoyed over 10 years in the mobile industry, including experience running a VC funded mobile start up, working for a large mobile operator and a few years consulting. With his J2ME and XHTML years behind him, Richard now supports Android developers bringing excellent apps to the Android Market.

Nick is an Android Developer Advocate at Google based in London.  He has a passion for Android and all things mobile. With an eye for detail, Nick is focused on helping designing sublime user interfaces and wonderfully functional apps.

After moving to Berlin in 2009 Benjamin started developing Applications for Android. Shortly after that he became manager of Berlin's Android Usergroup "Android in Berlin" wich holds monthly meetups. He has co-organized Android related community events such as "GTUG Community Weekend" and "Global Android Dev Camp". 
While studying Business Computing he and his team developed the Guinness World Record holding Open Source App Blinkendroid. Further is a member of c-base hackerspace's mobile interfaces project that is currently focusing on home automation. 
Benjamin works at ImmobilienScout24 as a Senior Software Developer.
Richard started programming in 1985 with a CPC 464. Now he develops software for Android and the server side at etc-consult. He is co-lead of GDG Berlin and also active in other groups.

Dirk Jäckel develops Android Apps since late 2008 when he bought his first Android phone. He is a co-host of the german Pandroid podcast. Dirk is a full time employee at Neofonie Mobile GmbH since 2011.

As a developer advocate at Google, Matt works with developers & partners in Europe to bring applications and content to the Google TV platform. Prior to joining Google in 2012, he was a software engineer at Future Platforms, a cross-platform mobile development house.

Jan is based in Berlin where he has been working on the audio platform SoundCloud for the past three years, originally starting as a back-end developer. However his side interest
in Android has led to a few open-source projects and eventually the involvement in building SoundCloud's official Android client. More recently he started delving into ObjectiveC and iOS to see what's happening on the other side of the fence.
Andreas Krennmair is working as a backend developer for a large German webhosting company and spends his free time developing and improving various open-source projects.

Daniel Kurka has been a web developer for almost 15 years. He is a member of the Google Web Toolkit steering committee that drives GWT development. Since 2009 he is building mobile Apps with GWT and Phonegap and has released two open source projects that have become the standard for building mobile apps with GWT: mgwt & gwt-phonegap.
Katharina Fahnenbruck is a software consultant with a great interest in (mobile) web technologies. She is responsible for the developer outreach of  mgwt and gwt-phonegap.

Gerwin Sturm is an independent software developer from Vienna, who always loves to try out new stuff. At the moment he
primarily focusses on the various Google+ APIs.

Tim Messerschmidt is a long-time mobile & web developer. In his current position as Developer Evangelist for PayPal he’s coordinating the developer activities for Germany, Austria & Swiss. Tim is passionate about working with startups, developers & geeks in general and is always looking forward to a good hackathon. Prior to his job at PayPal Tim worked as a Technical Project Manager & Software Engineer at the mobile agency Neofonie Mobile GmbH in Berlin. Having studied Business Informatics at the University of Paderborn in Germany, he is passionate about topics like eCommerce – this helped him in activities like consulting Samsung Deutschland GmbH as Developer Advocate and running his own business.

As a developer advocate, Paul is dedicated to helping developers make the most out of Google's developer products, focusing primarily on the Google Maps APIs.  He helps developers build cool and compelling apps, advocates for them with our product and engineering teams, and fosters communities working with Google technologies.  As an informaticist, Paul looks for new ways to make (geospatial) data perceptible to the mind and imagination.  Before Google, Paul was an academic biomedical informaticist, using data and visualizations to help find cures for diseases.
